title: Mercury opposition Venus
summary: Thought and taste face each other. Conversations about preferences, money, or relationships may reveal gaps between logic and desire. The opportunity is to communicate values clearly without forcing agreement.

meaning.headline: Ideas and values sit across the table, asking to be reconciled.

frames.text: Mercury-Venus oppositions highlight tension between what makes sense and what feels appealing.
Negotiations may surface where communication style differs from relational expectations.
You might notice a split between practical choices and aesthetic or emotional preferences.
This can be a productive moment to clarify budgets, timelines, or social plans.
This aspect forces conflict or proves someone is selfish.

frictions: Using charm to bypass clear agreements
Taking feedback about money or taste personally
Indecision when logic and preference clash
opportunities: Naming what you like and why
Drafting agreements that respect both fairness and feeling
Learning someone else's preferences without judgment

do: State your preferences and the reasons behind them.
Ask what matters most to the other side.
Check assumptions about tone-clarify if unsure.
Use numbers or examples to ground a conversation about value.
Separate disagreement about taste from judgments of worth.
avoid: Pleasing others by hiding real needs
Critiquing style when the issue is structure
Making promises to avoid temporary discomfort

reusable_lines.text: Let logic and preference both speak so decisions stay honest.
You can stay kind without skipping clarity.

forbidden_claims: Moral judgments about taste or spending
allowed_framing: Supportive framing: can highlight differences to work with
Agency-forward language: you choose how to communicate values
Contextual framing: conversations about preference may feel louder today
